arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees; logical extension of Girja Bai; next friend acts for minor.

anchor.surface_text: On June 20, 1942, the defendants filed their written statements, wherein they claimed that the purchase of items 2 and 11 had been made with the separate funds of the second and third defendants, and that the joint family had no title to them. They further alleged that the family had debts to the extent of Rs. 2,600.

arguments.court_reasoning: Ill-treatment not established; but sales/purchases showed adverse intent via later claims.

holdings.text: There was no concurrent finding by the courts below that the suit was not instituted for the benefit of the minor; the Subordinate Judge misdirected himself, and the High Court had power to reverse it in second appeal as it was a misdirection.

anchor.surface_text: that it is a pure question of fact whether the institution of a suit is for the benefit of a minor or not, and that a finding of the courts below on that question is not liable to be interfered with in second appeal. But it must be observed that the finding of the Subordinate Judge was only that as the impugned sale and purchases were made before the minor plaintiff was born, no cause of action for partition could be founded by him thereon, and that, in our opinion, is a clear misdirection.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts focused on pre-birth transactions ignoring post-birth adverse claims in written statements denying title and alleging debts; constitutes misdirection allowing interference.

holdings.text: The suit for partition does not abate on the death of the minor plaintiff before the court decides on benefit; legal representatives can continue and prove benefit, with severance from suit date.

anchor.surface_text: when a minor plaintiff dies before the court adjudicates on the question of benefit to him, he dies an undivided coparcener and his interest survives to the other coparceners and does not devolve on his heirs by inheritance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Next friend institutes suit effecting conditional severance; court approves; follows Rangasayi, Ramsing, Mandliprasad; rejects Chelimi Chetty as erroneous.

holdings.text: Institution of partition suit by next friend on behalf of minor coparcener effects division in status from date of suit, conditional upon court finding it beneficial to minor.

anchor.surface_text: that a division in status takes place when he expresses his intention to become separate unequivocally and unambiguously, that the filing of a suit for partition is a clear expression of such an intention, and that, in consequence,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Extends Girja Bai and Kawal Nain to minors via next friend; court approves volition expressed by next friend, does not create it; extra-court partitions by relations valid.

holdings.text: Under Mitakshara law, minor coparcener has right to partition exercisable through next friend, subject to court satisfaction that suit is for his benefit.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Mitakshara law, the right, of a coparcener to share in the joint family properties arises on his birth, and that right carries with it the right to be maintained out of those properties suitably to the status of the family so long as the family is joint and to have a partition and separate possession of his share, should he make a demand for it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No distinction between major and minor coparceners' rights; suit maintainable if beneficial.

holdings.text: The maxim actio personalis moritur cum persona does not apply to partition suits, which are proprietary not personal, so no abatement on minor's death.

anchor.surface_text: the suit must abate on the principle of the maxim, actio personalis moritur cum persona. But that maxim has application only when the action is one for damages for a personal wrong, and as a suit for partition is a suit for property, the rule in question has no application to it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Maxim limited to personal wrongs/damages; partition seeks property rights.

holdings.text: Court's jurisdiction to require satisfaction of benefit in minor's partition suit derives from parens patriae doctrine to protect minors' interests.

anchor.surface_text: the theory is that the Sovereign as parens patriae has the power, and is indeed under a duty to protect the interests of minors, and that function has devolved on the courts. In the discharge of that function, therefore, they have the power to control all proceedings before them wherein minors are concerned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inherent jurisdiction over minors independent of Hindu law; approves next friend's action.

holdings.text: Chelimi Chetty, Lalta Prasad, Hari Singh erroneous: court does not create minor's volition for severance; next friend/relation does, court approves if beneficial.

anchor.surface_text: While the decisions in Chelimi Chetty v. Subbamma 1 , Lalta Prasad v. Sri Mahadeoji Birajman Temple 2 and Hari Singh Pritam Singh 3 , hold that when a suit for partition is filed on behalf of a minor plaintiff there is a division in status only if and when the Court decides that it is for his benefit and passes a decree

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ratio of those cases wrong; court recognizes next friend's declaration; analogous to extra-court partitions by guardians/relations.

holdings.text: Rangasayi, Ramsing, Mandliprasad correct: severance relates back to suit institution date if beneficial.

anchor.surface_text: the decisions in Rangasayi v. Nagarathnamma 4 , Ramsing v. Fakira 5 and Mandliprasad v. Ramcharanlal 6 , lay down that when such a suit is decreed, the severance in status relates back to the date of the institution of the suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical extension of Girja Bai to minors; agrees with Full Bench.

anchor.surface_text: that it is a pure question of fact whether the institution of a suit is for the benefit of a minor or not, and that a finding of the courts below on that question is not liable to be interfered with in second appeal. But it must be observed that the finding of the Subordinate Judge was only that as the impugned sale and purchases were made before the minor plaintiff was born, no cause of action for partition could be founded by him thereon, and that, in our opinion, is a clear misdirection.
That was the view taken in Rangasayi v. Nagarathnamma 1 at pp. 137-138 and in Mandliprasad v. Ramcharanlal 2 at p. 871, and we are in agreement with it.

anchor.surface_text: when a minor plaintiff dies before the court adjudicates on the question of benefit to him, he dies an undivided coparcener and his interest survives to the other coparceners and does not devolve on his heirs by inheritance.
That was the view taken in Rangasayi v. Nagarathnamma 1 at pp. 137-138 and in Mandliprasad v. Ramcharanlal 2 at p. 871, and we are in agreement with it.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Mitakshara law, the right, of a coparcener to share in the joint family properties arises on his birth, and that right carries with it the right to be maintained out of those properties suitably to the status of the family so long as the family is joint and to have a partition and separate possession of his share, should he make a demand for it.
That was the view taken in Rangasayi v. Nagarathnamma 1 at pp. 137-138 and in Mandliprasad v. Ramcharanlal 2 at p. 871, and we are in agreement with it.

anchor.surface_text: the suit must abate on the principle of the maxim, actio personalis moritur cum persona. But that maxim has application only when the action is one for damages for a personal wrong, and as a suit for partition is a suit for property, the rule in question has no application to it.
That was the view taken in Rangasayi v. Nagarathnamma 1 at pp. 137-138 and in Mandliprasad v. Ramcharanlal 2 at p. 871, and we are in agreement with it.

the theory is that the Sovereign as parens patriae has the power, and is indeed under a duty to protect the interests of minors, and that function has devolved on the courts. In the discharge of that function, therefore, they have the power to control all proceedings before them wherein minors are concerned.
That was the view taken in Rangasayi v. Nagarathnamma 1 at pp. 137-138 and in Mandliprasad v. Ramcharanlal 2 at p. 871, and we are in agreement with it.
